The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and compare these to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. This study also provides a useful example of how to use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to study the molecular mechanism of channel inhibition.

Climate change will affect crop yields, but the magnitude of the change depends on the temperature at which the crop is grown. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which species partition food resources is a key determinant of coexistence in nature. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because comprehensive species-level identification is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive and taxon-specific studies of diet partitioning in nature.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the verge of closure. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the extent to which they have already laid off workers and closed their doors. We also explore the financial fragility of small businesses and the extent to which they anticipate accessing the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. Finally, we assess the effects of the pandemic on small businesses by comparing the experiences of businesses that received loans relative to grants under the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act is likely to provide much-needed relief to many small businesses. However, the program is likely to be overwhelmed by demand, and many small businesses will be unable to access the funds they need.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show that the plastic debris is mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of the debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits in nature. In this study, we examine the factors that increase reproductive output and the strength of the effect of these factors across a wide range of species. We find that the most important factor is the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy can come from the mother herself (allocare) or from the offspring (allonursing). Domestication also increases the amount of energy available to the mother, but the effect is smaller than that of allocare and allonursing. These results suggest that the most important factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for the evolution of reproductive strategies in nature and the domestication process. It also suggests that the reproductive output of a species is a good indicator of its metabolic power.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 prevented motor deficits in the mouse model and reduced α-syn load in the striatum of the mouse model. More importantly, VX-765 showed neuroprotective effects by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the primary site of vascular disease and is the target of many drugs. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control many important physiological functions. It does so by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that allows them to rapidly and efficiently integrate information. This organization is effective in controlling the endothelium’s many functions. The endothelium is the target of many drugs, and understanding its organization may help us to design better drugs.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are essential for understanding the pandemic and for making decisions about how to respond. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This structural coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is constantly changing in response to the environment and the host. The role of the microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for natural products to regulate the microbiome is being explored. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and bacteriocins. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the microbiome. This work provides a foundation for future studies to investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of social hierarchy are poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify an important role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region implicated in social behavior, in the establishment of social hierarchy. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work provides a molecular basis for the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. (Show more)

The ability to design and fabricate mechanical structures with programmable responses is highly desired for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of programmable mechanical structures. It is expected to inspire the development of mechanical systems with programmable responses in a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the heterochronous regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. In addition, we show that IGF2BP1 can reverse the adult hemoglobin pattern in primary human erythroid tissues. This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A, which is a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This knowledge may be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. It may also be relevant to the understanding of the evolution of the hemoglobin system.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Mechanistically, this resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with heart failure in elderly patients. We show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism involving STIM/ORAI. This mechanism of action is important to understand the adverse effects of these drugs in elderly patients and patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP was successful in halting clearcutting, but this has not yet been sufficient to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy, and our findings highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and expensive process, which is why it is essential to identify promising candidates as early as possible. Here, we present a computational approach to identify promising acylide antibiotics that can be used to treat antibiotic-resistant infections. We show that our approach is able to predict the activity of the compounds in vitro and in vivo. The best compound designed by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is able to treat infections caused by antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This approach can be used to identify promising candidates for the treatment of antibiotic-resistant infections. The compounds designed by us are available for further development.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with large datasets. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the biosphere and geosphere, and the tropics are a major source of global water vapor. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is a 1,300-y period of abrupt climate change that began abruptly at the end of the Holocene Epoch and ended abruptly at the start of the late Bronze Age. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and organ-specific autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, the disease was not fatal. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for the maintenance of tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. This work provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can enable expanded antibody breadth and improved potency by ∼10- to 600-fold against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD, and APOE genotype is the most important risk factor for AD susceptibility. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, where it is produced by astrocytes. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may be a consequence of defective phagocytic capacity of APOE4 astrocytes. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be more susceptible to AD because of defective astrocytic phagocytosis, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses and their vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is testable in animal models. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 1,300 km in radius. It is the densest part of the planet and is the fastest rotating object in the solar system. The inner core is a mystery because it is difficult to form and is stable for billions of years. We show that the inner core formed by nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is metastable at core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also suggest that the inner core may be a promising site for studying the physics of supercooled liquids.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available, and its use is increasing. The drug is also associated with a range of negative consequences, including impaired cognition, violence, and motor vehicle accidents. The present study provides evidence that the brain’s reactivity to the drug is reduced in people who abuse marijuana. This reduced reactivity may contribute to the drug’s negative consequences.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and its neural basis is a major open question in neuroscience. We show that the most accurate computational models of language processing in the field also outperform humans on this task, and that model performance correlates with their fit to the data in key ways. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the language system may be more modular than previously thought, with many small, similar modules distributed across cortex, each focused on a different subcomputational step in processing language. Such a modular organization could facilitate the rapid application of this ability across human history. Our results also raise the possibility that the language system may be more similar to vision than previously thought, with a smaller core and surrounding “deep” networks performing predictive processing at different levels of abstraction. Such a modular organization could facilitate the rapid application of this ability across human history. Our approach is generalizable to other cognitive and neural processes, and to other species. We hope it will become a standard tool in the neuroscience toolkit. (Less)

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still unclear how to design stable DL algorithms that can be used in practice. In this paper, we study the stability of neural networks and prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This is a fundamental result that clarifies the gap between theory and practice in DL. It also provides a classification theory for stability, which can be used to design stable DL algorithms. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network algorithm that is stable and provably converges to a solution with a given accuracy. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is the first step toward designing stable DL algorithms in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a textbook example of exponential growth. The exponential growth curve is a staple of introductory biology and mathematics courses, and it is also a common feature of many other fields of research. However, the exponential growth curve is not a scientific construct. It is a mathematical model that is only useful for predicting the future, but not for understanding the past. This paper discusses the limitations of the exponential growth curve and the classic experiment that popularizes it.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and its etiology is still not fully understood. We sequenced the genome of a patient with leprosy and identified a new species, Mycobacterium lepromatosis. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and the mechanisms that lead to the development of the two major forms of the disease, lepromatous and leprae. The results also suggest that the two leprosy pathogens are still closely related and may be able to cause similar diseases in humans. This knowledge may help to develop new treatments for leprosy. The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of infinite system size and large time. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain. Our result is a step toward a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and caused severe economic damage. The only available vaccines are not 100% effective, and the pandemic is far from being under control. Therefore, the development of a highly effective, safe, and broadly protective vaccine is a global priority. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is highly attenuated, induces strong immune responses, and protects against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to control the pandemic. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature, ensuring large-scale manufacturing. The vaccine is also easy to manufacture at large scale, which is essential for mass vaccination programs. These features, coupled with the fact that the vaccine is based on a segment of the viral spike protein, which engages with the host immune system, make this vaccine a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using Bayesian inference to model mortality data. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not a single epidemic but rather a series of recurrent epidemics, which may have had a significant impact on the history of Europe. The common cold is the most common infectious disease worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. The mechanism of temperature-dependent growth is not known. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adherent pili to sense surfaces and respond accordingly. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the type IV pili, a major surface adhesin, and is regulated by a chemosensory system that regulates the production of the second messenger cAMP. The chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the pilin subunit of the type IV pili and is required for the mechanosensory response. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing provides a mechanism for how bacteria can sense the mechanical activity of their surface-adherent pili and respond accordingly. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface water are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This is of particular importance in view of the increasing resistance of aquatic organisms to pesticides.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the persistence of the virus in animal reservoirs is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple lineages of the virus in deer and humans. Our findings suggest that deer are susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection and could act as reservoirs for the virus. The presence of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, and the ongoing circulation of the virus in deer populations, has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. A proactive “One Health” approach is needed to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to the development of effective strategies to mitigate the risk of future viral spillover events. (Show more)

The world is moving toward a low-carbon future. This is a good thing. However, the world is still building large dams in the developing world. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and there is no cure. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. The immune system is often blamed for the neurotoxicity of Aβ, but the evidence for this is circumstantial. We show that Aβ itself is not sufficient to trigger an immune response in neurons, but that the toxic effects of Aβ are amplified when neurons are exposed to soluble Aβ species. We also show that the toxic effects of Aβ are localized to specific regions of the brain, suggesting that the immune response may be localized to these regions as well. These findings suggest that the immune system may play a more important role in AD pathogenesis than previously thought.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. But how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a bottom-up parser that merges words into phrases, and it is also consistent with a model of language in which the brain uses the probability of a word given the previous word as its only cue. Our results suggest that the brain uses probability as a heuristic to build syntactic structures. This heuristic may be useful in noisy environments, when the brain is unable to access the full context of a word. Our findings provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed forest monitoring is a key tool for monitoring and mitigating this threat. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of reconstructed genomes is too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. This increased dataset enabled us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate change science. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to massive emissions of CO2 to the atmosphere. We show that soil management practices that maintain or increase crop rotations and integrate livestock can sequester SOC and reduce emissions. These practices are particularly effective in perennial pastures, which sequester more SOC and particulate organic carbon than annual cropping systems. Our results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester soil carbon and provide a framework for climate-smart agriculture. This work is a step toward a more sustainable future for agriculture and the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and cause pandemics. We also present a publicly accessible web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize their own research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce colorful nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid compound, nesocodin. We also show that the red color of the nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited plant, is also derived from nesocodin. These findings suggest that the red color of colorful nectar is a convergent trait that is favored by natural selection. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait that is essential for plant reproduction. It also provides a new class of natural product that can be used as a chemical marker for the study of plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th to 7th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present the genome sequence of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 480 and 680 AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. This heterogeneity is particularly striking in women with artificial skull deformations, who appear to have originated in southeastern Europe. In addition, we find that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This work is a step toward the development of a cloud-based pathogen surveillance platform for resource-scarce settings. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. These results also provide a foundation for future studies on the mechanism of DNA polymerase recycling and exchange. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, in vitro evolution was used to improve dramatically the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme by selecting variants that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical mechanisms that drive urban change. (Abridged)

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We have identified that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality. Therefore, tocilizumab is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a mechanism to sequester copper, but the mechanism is not understood. We report here that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in A. fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide that is secreted into the growth medium. The secreted isocyanide binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. The secreted isocyanide also has antimicrobial properties, including inhibition of the fungal virulence factor laccase. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the role of natural products in fungal interactions with other microbes. This work also provides a model for the evolution of a fungal metal-binding natural product. This work demonstrates the importance of studying the metal homeostasis of fungi, which are essential microbes that are often overlooked in metal homeostasis studies. The formation of silica polymorphs in sedimentary rocks is rare on Earth and on Mars. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a rare silica polymorph in sedimentary rocks on Earth and because the sedimentary rock is cogenetic with the other minerals in the sample. The sedimentary rock is a fine-grained, laminated mudstone that formed in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The sedimentary rock is a detrital assemblage of tridymite, cristobalite, plagioclase, cation-deficient magnetite, sanidine, and an amorphous silica phase. The amorphous silica phase is a rare silica phase in sedimentary rocks on Earth and on Mars. The sedimentary rock is a possible source for the silicic volcanism in the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak region.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that this change is already affecting the performance of forests. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk and to minimize the economic and ecological damage of frost damage.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the pathogenesis of colitis by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. This is important because it suggests that therapies that target Th17 cells may be effective in treating certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. This also suggests that therapies that target the enteric microbiota may be effective in treating other types of inflammatory bowel disease. Thus, Th17 cells may be a useful therapeutic target in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical courses. There is a need for disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify treatments. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, enabling disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This method will enable the study of the disease in living patients and the development of treatments. This will improve the lives of ALS patients and their families. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-harbored human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota to facilitate infection. We demonstrate that A. phagocytophilum induces the tick to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the tick gut microbiota and perturbs the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of life. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is obscured by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”). Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. This study also provides important new information about the origin of the flight apparatus and the evolution of mosaic evolution in birds. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of feedbacks. In this paper, we show that the role of the stratosphere in the climate system is more important than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a wide variety of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate its identity, warn of danger, or blend into its environment. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein binds biliverdin, the pigment that gives blood its red color. This discovery provides a molecular basis for the evolution of color in animals and may help us understand the evolution of color in plants.

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is a key feature of metastasis and resistance to therapy. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cell properties. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced in response to hypoxia, which may contribute to the maintenance of the cancer stem cell phenotype. This study provides insight into the role of ALKBH5 in the tumor microenvironment and the regulation of breast cancer stem cells. This knowledge may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The earliest Bibles were written on animal skins, and the parchment used to make them was a major source of income for the medieval economy. The source of this parchment, however, has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the medieval period. The results suggest that the use of fetal animals was not necessary to produce the first pocket Bibles. Instead, the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction depends on precise dating of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China. The age model is based on five volcanic ash beds that mark the onset of the extinction and its recovery. The age model is precise to within 48 ka, and the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya. The carbon cycle was highly volatile immediately preceding the extinction, and the carbon cycle continued to be volatile for ∼500 ka, a period of time that is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. The age model for the extinction provides a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most prevalent in currently circulating viruses, and it is hypothesized to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the D614G and G614 spikes and show that the G614 spike is more open and flexible, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may not increase infectivity and may be beneficial for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is applied to show that, under mild assumptions, the set of Nash equilibria of a repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs is a Borel set. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to the understanding of the chemical world. The chemical properties of atoms are also the basis of the chemical behavior of molecules and, ultimately, of all matter. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is a general trend for most elements. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under extreme conditions.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but this is not the case everywhere. In some regions, human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of fire regimes. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, the risk is that more extreme fires will occur elsewhere, and that climate change will exacerbate this. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to understand the role of human ignitions and fire suppression in future fire regimes.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most important interactions in nature. The precise nature of the symbiont and the host’s response to it are critical determinants of the symbiosis’s stability. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the stability of a symbiosis between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the glycan is delivered only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is metabolically active. These results suggest that the glycan is a specific cue that the host uses to regulate the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in symbiosis, and it suggests that the delivery of specific nutrients may be a general strategy for regulating the activities of symbionts in their host’s tissues.

The study of topics in text is a central problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to analyze the narratives of violent deaths reported to the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the narratives contain latent topics that are not captured by the structured variables used to summarize the data. We also find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics is consistent with known biases in semantic space. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, including medical records, social media, and legal documents. It can also be used to study the gendered nature of topics in text.

The Black Death, originating in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the origins of the second plague pandemic and the role of climate change in its spread. It also highlights the importance of long-term climate monitoring in the study of past pandemics. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. Mass mortality events of asteroids are rare and have been linked to epizootics of viruses. Here, we provide evidence that a densovirus is the causative agent of the sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) that has caused extensive mortality of asteroids in the Northeast Pacific. The virus was detected in symptomatic asteroids as well as in sediments and plankton, suggesting that it can spread over long distances. The SSaDV is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and the Middle East to the Malagasy population. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is revealed by the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent settlement from Africa and Asia, but also a long history of admixture, which is still detectable in the present genomic diversity. The results suggest that Madagascar was settled by several independent groups, rather than by a single group that was already admixed.

Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by showing that the Crop Condition Index derived from the crop expert assessments is more accurate than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that crop experts are a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural monitoring and forecasting systems. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

Language is a uniquely human ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. The brain mechanisms that support this ability are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can bind linguistic features over time. The model is able to capture the effects of interference and decay in memory. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can bind linguistic features over time. The model is able to capture the effects of interference and decay in memory. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major function, photosynthesis, and the acquisition of a new function, the acquisition of nutrients. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This stepwise relaxation of functional constraints may be a general feature of the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of extreme droughts in southwestern South Africa is large. The contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was estimated to be a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal, which was formed in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form and the potential for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The discovery of this quasicrystal also provides a unique link between the past and the present, as it was formed in the immediate aftermath of the first nuclear explosion.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. (Bacterio)chlorophylls have an isocyclic fifth ring, the formation of which has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K). However, the precise roles of these signaling pathways in neuroinflammation remain unclear. In this study, we found that apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a key regulator of neuroinflammation in EAE. ASK1 is highly expressed in microglia/macrophages and plays a major role in the later stage of EAE. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the early stage of EAE, whereas deficiency in astrocytes ameliorated the later stage of EAE. These findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the early stage, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of EAE. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. This work provides a strong case for taking action to reduce the risk of future droughts.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that people do, in fact, react more strongly to negative news content, but that this negativity bias is not universal. Rather, it is highly variable across individuals, and it is also highly variable across countries. The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular aggregate myopathy in patients with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is mediated by endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the plasma membrane. These results demonstrate that the mechanisms of spreading of aggregates in Drosophila are similar to those in mammals and suggest that the mechanisms of spreading of aggregates in Drosophila and mammals are similar. This study provides a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of aggregates in the brain and for developing therapeutics to prevent the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases.
