Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the leukotriene-A4 hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase to inhibit leukotriene B4 (LTB4) generation, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on leukotriene-A4 hydrolase or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a metabolic target. We report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings provide a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of DLBCL. They also provide a scaffold for the development of more potent and selective SHMT inhibitors. Finally, they provide a rationale for the use of formate as a rescue one-carbon donor in the treatment of cancer. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies. These inclusions contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and suggests that the inclusion bodies in ALS are a result of a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of aquatic angiosperms is even less understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous period. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that was previously misinterpreted and poorly understood. Based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but it is difficult to study because of the small number of viral genomes available. Here we present 10 viral genomes from ancient human remains, which show that the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient DNA can be extracted from ancient human remains, which can be used to study the evolution of other pathogens. This is an important step forward in our understanding of the evolution of viruses.

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a strong indication that the climate system is changing, and the rate of rise is consistent with the projections of climate models forced by increasing greenhouse gas concentrations. The acceleration is not explained by changes in human land use, and it is not explained by changes in the climate system other than the melting of glaciers and ice sheets.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The ability to characterize the structure of enzyme active sites at the atomic level is a key goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach is able to provide atomic-resolution characterization of the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. Most notable is the water molecule immediately adjacent to the substrate β-carbon, which serves as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the βLys87 catalytic residue. This detailed picture of structure and reactivity emerges, highlighting the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. Reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with benzimidazole, an isostere of the natural substrate indole, shows benzimidazole bound in the active site and poised for, but unable to initiate, the subsequent bond formation step. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum antiviral that has shown efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease and reduced virus replication and lung lesions. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as there is currently no specific treatment for this disease. The availability of remdesivir would also be of great importance for the treatment of other viral diseases, such as Ebola, where there is no specific treatment.

The symbiotic associations that animals form with microbes are among the most important interactions in nature. The precise nature of the symbiont and the host’s response to it are critical determinants of the symbiosis’s stability. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the stability of a symbiosis between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. This glycan is released by the host at a specific time of day, and the host’s response to it is specific to the symbiont. This glycan may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts.

The suspension of students from school is a common and controversial practice. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which in turn bolsters students’ respect for teachers and their motivation to behave well in class. This intervention has the potential to reduce suspensions and improve the quality of teacher–student relationships. It is scalable, requires minimal teacher effort, and can be implemented in any school.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the majority of the population have a large impact on these emissions, and so there is a strong case for increasing the proportion of plant-based meals in catering settings. However, it is difficult to change people’s behavior, and so it is important to understand the potential for simple interventions to nudge people toward more sustainable diets. We show that doubling the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering setting increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 61% and decreased the proportion of meat meals purchased by 14%. These results suggest that it is feasible to make a large contribution to the sustainability of the food system by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. The 2020 presidential election will be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. As a result, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral effects. This is an important finding for election administration experts and policymakers alike.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a high mortality rate and a rapid spread. The molecular basis for the severity of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. It also provides a structural basis for the development of antiviral therapeutics and vaccines. This work is expected to aid in the development of effective treatments and vaccines for the COVID-19 pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise depends on the ability to find associations in data. This is a difficult task, however, because of the many sources of error. In this paper we address the problem of “selective inference,” which is the need to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We illustrate the use of selective inference in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help scientists to be more aware of the challenges and pitfalls of association discovery.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many transcription factors have been identified, the minimum number of factors that are required to induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we show that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the development of ECs from primary human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in vivo. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. These results indicate that ETV2 provides a useful tool for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling receptors that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In addition, they are frequently mutated in cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function of the orphan RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that zebrafish deficient in the two ligands of Alk and Ltk display a severe defect in pigment patterning. These defects are mediated by the ligand-activated receptor Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the physiological role of augmentor ligands and the mechanisms by which they are activated by Ltk. It also provides a model system for studying the role of ligand-activated RTKs in vivo. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and pigment-related diseases.

β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). The role of STING in β-cell function is unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion, which may be useful for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for T2D. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging of the viral genome is essential for the production of infectious viral particles. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. It also provides a molecular basis for the selective packaging of the viral genome. This knowledge is essential for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential formation of atherosclerotic lesions. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in the United States in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that physical improvements are more likely to occur in neighborhoods that are more diverse and that are more attractive to people with higher levels of education. These results have implications for urban planning and for the study of urban change more generally.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from pests. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster mediates avoidance behavior to natural repellents. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV pathogenesis are not fully understood, but the dynamics of ZIKV within the host are likely to play an important role. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results provide insights into the potential impact of antiviral treatment on the course of ZIKV infection. They also highlight the importance of early treatment initiation, which is difficult to achieve in humans due to the lack of a rapid diagnostic test. Our results suggest that the timing of treatment initiation may be critical for the efficacy of antiviral treatment against ZIKV. These findings are of particular importance in the context of the ongoing Zika virus outbreak in Latin America, where the timing of treatment initiation is critical for the success of the ongoing control efforts

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, the single-celled algae that live inside the coral cells and provide the coral with nutrients and color. The loss of the symbiosis is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs, but the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. This study provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work also provides a new perspective on the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiome. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium, leading to a loss of barrier function and dysbiotic microbiome. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between tumorigenesis and host–microbe homeostasis. They also suggest that targeting JNK signaling or the microbiome may be a promising strategy to treat intestinal tumors and restore host–microbe homeostasis. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are estrogen receptor-positive, a small fraction of these tumors are resistant to endocrine therapy. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a small fraction of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1, which are key regulators of breast cancer stemness. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the efficacy of chemotherapy in eradicating these tumors. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation is instead linked to a volcanic eruption series, with the eruptions coinciding with the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly linked the eruptions to the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can impact climate and the climate system, and how climate impacts can be linked to specific events. This is important for understanding the climate system and its response to external forcing. It also provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can be used to constrain climate history. The Mount Takahe eruption series is the most extensive volcanic eruption series found in ice cores, and the only one that is synchronous with deglaciation. The Takahe eruptions are also the only volcanic eruption series that are synchronous with deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where alternative sources of protein are scarce. Our analysis highlights the need for improved management of freshwater fisheries, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. This analysis underscores the need for improved management of freshwater fisheries, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of life, and the nervous system is particularly dependent on this ability. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost, and the few remaining neurons are unable to regenerate effectively. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for gene discovery in the field of neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning, a phenomenon that produces robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken together, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. This work may lead to the development of new regenerative therapies for the nervous system. (Show more)

Recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in populations and species. In humans and mice, hotspots of recombination are known to occur in the promoter regions of genes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus, which is interspersed with hotspots of varying strengths. The hotspots are interspersed with cold regions of undetectably low recombination, and the average recombination rate peaks near the start of genes and falls off sharply, exhibiting polarity. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This study provides a detailed view of recombination in a wild plant population, which is a rare and valuable resource for evolutionary studies. It also provides a model for studying the evolution of recombination in a natural population.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of the brain’s many functionally distinct regions. The functional organization of the brain is thought to be reflected in the spatial pattern of these fluctuations. Here, we show that the spatial pattern of fluctuations in metabolic brain activity can be used to identify the brain’s functional organization. We also show that this organization can be used to identify and validate the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects and in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on some small RNAs, such as the 5′ NAD+ RNA in bacteria. Here we show that the 5′ NAD+ RNA is also found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. We propose that the 5′ NAD+ RNA could modulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ RNA could be a new modification of mRNA that is conserved between bacteria and eukaryotes.

The ability of epigenetic DNA-methylation patterns to persist over time and to be associated with the risk of diabetes complications has been demonstrated. However, the mechanisms by which epigenetic DNA-me patterns are associated with diabetes complications are not known. Here, we show that epigenetic DNA-me patterns at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that these DNA-me patterns are associated with the risk of complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that high glucose induces persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in monocytes, suggesting that epigenetic DNA-me patterns at TXNIP may be a mechanism for the association of TXNIP with diabetes complications. These results provide evidence for the persistence of epigenetic DNA-me patterns over time and their association with diabetes complications. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in TNBC drug sensitivity has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of alcohol dependence is complex and involves genetic and environmental factors. The present study suggests that the gut microbiota may play a role in the development of alcohol dependence. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of alcohol dependence and suggests that the gut microbiota may be a promising target for the development of new treatment strategies. The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both fundamental and applied reasons. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in plants and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of fields.

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these threats are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the future of the world’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior in mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for place learning, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they exhibit strong coupling among themselves but weaker coupling to other cell types. These results suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network that is not directly coupled to other cell types. This organization could facilitate the formation of a robust and stable representation of local space. Understanding the organization of MEC will be critical for understanding the neural basis of navigation and memory. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. In this study, we show that the flowering of the host plant is required for the flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The precise nature of the cell body and fiber changes that occur in the disease is not known. Here we show that the dopamine-containing cell bodies of the nigral neurons are clustered within the striatonigral fibers that innervate the striatum. These clustered cell bodies form specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This study provides insight into the nature of the cell bodies and fibers that are affected in Parkinson’s disease and may help to explain the behavioral changes that are observed in the disease. This work also provides a model for studying the organization of the dopamine-containing nigral system. This model could be used to study the effects of drugs that target the dopamine system and to study the effects of genetic mutations that affect the dopamine system. The striosome–dendron bouquets could be a target for such studies.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is regulated by the internal Ca2+ store and the plasma membrane. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in regulating SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the beneficial effects of Si on plant resistance against abiotic stresses have been well documented, the role of Si in mediating plant defense against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by jasmonic acid (JA), a key molecule in plant defense. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact synergistically in mediating resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the function of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage function.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the internalization of DNA nanostructures into plant cells and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. The world’s largest lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can harm fisheries and recreational activities. The most common cause of eutrophication is the discharge of excess nutrients from surrounding watersheds. However, the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our results reveal that small watersheds can be a significant source of nutrients to the nearshore zone, especially when they drain urbanized areas. This finding suggests that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, which are often overlooked in regulatory efforts and monitoring programs. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and provide a blueprint for future efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. The study of chemical networks in the far-from-equilibrium regime is a rapidly growing field of research. However, the mechanisms that govern the emergence of far-from-equilibrium states are not well understood. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that makes strong forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the extremization of environmental forcing may be a general mechanism for the emergence of far-from-equilibrium states in complex systems. This finding may have important implications for the design of synthetic chemical systems that are capable of operating in the far-from-equilibrium regime. It may also provide a new perspective on the design of chemical systems that are capable of operating in the far-from-equilibrium regime.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with widespread anoxia and that this event was driven by changes in the ocean circulation. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that drive abrupt climate change and the potential for such changes to occur in the future.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. We find that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the function of all organisms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a key determinant of reproductive success. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent, and the sex of an individual is either male or female. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual can be male, female, or intersex. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. They also suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple sex determination alleles may be a general feature of polygenic sex determination.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptors and RPE cells, respectively. The photoreceptor-derived ROS are quenched by the RPE, but the RPE is challenged by the RPE-derived ROS that are generated by the accumulation of the bisretinoid A2E. We show that the intracellular levels of iron (Fe) impact the retina. In particular, we show that Fe levels are reduced in albino mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone. This reduction in Fe levels reduced the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. These findings suggest that Fe levels impact the retina and may be a target for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (A2E, 2-aminoterephthalic acid; ROS, reactive oxygen species.)

Predators are the key to understanding how life on Earth works. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their prey. Our results suggest that specialization is a recurrent evolutionary process, and that the evolution of specialization can be linked to the evolution of other traits. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure that has evolved over millions of years. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, is from an early Middle Pleistocene hominin from Kenya. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding provides insight into the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand function. It also provides a new fossil record for the evolution of the human hand that can be used to better understand the evolution of the human lineage. This fossil is also the earliest hominin fossil to be recovered from the Turkana Basin, a region that has been the focus of intense research for the past 50 y. The fossil is also the first hominin fossil to be recovered from the West Turkana region. The West Turkana region is a region of high biodiversity and is the focus of intense research for the next 50 y.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and, in turn, their health and livelihoods.

The widespread occurrence of subsoil compaction in modern agriculture has been attributed to the increase in vehicle weight. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has not been the only factor driving compaction, but that the increase in vehicle size has also contributed to the problem. We develop a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility and show that the risk of subsoil compaction is now higher than at any time in the last 10,000 y. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by recent evidence of the use of fixed trails by sauropods.
